cards.originalText:

• Tap target creature you don't control.
• Put a -1/-1 counter on target tapped creature an opponent controls.

rulings.text: The ability is mandatory, and if there are no legal targets for the second mode, you must choose the first mode. For example, if the only creature on the battlefield is an untapped creature a teammate controls, you must tap it.

The first mode can target any creature you don't control, not just an untapped one. For example, if your teammate controls an untapped creature and a tapped creature, you can target the tapped creature with the first mode to avoid tapping the untapped one.

cards.name: Isolation Zone
cards.originalText: When Isolation Zone enters the battlefield, exile target creature or enchantment an opponent controls until Isolation Zone leaves the battlefield. (That permanent returns under its owner's control.)

rulings.text: If Isolation Zone leaves the battlefield before its triggered ability resolves, the target creature or enchantment won’t be exiled.

Auras attached to the exiled creature or enchantment will be put into their owners’ graveyards. Any Equipment will become unattached and remain on the battlefield. Any counters on the exiled permanent will cease to exist.
If a token is exiled, it ceases to exist. It won’t be returned to the battlefield.
The exiled card returns to the battlefield immediately after Isolation Zone leaves the battlefield. Nothing happens between the two events, including state-based actions.

In a multiplayer game, if Isolation Zone’s owner leaves the game, the exiled card will return to the battlefield. Because the one-shot effect that returns the card isn’t an ability that goes on the stack, it won’t cease to exist along with the leaving player’s spells and abilities on the stack.

cards.name: Runic Sealer
cards.originalText:
As Runic Sealer enters the battlefield, choose a noncreature, nonland card name.
Spells with the chosen name can't be cast.
Activated abilities of sources with the chosen name can't be activated.

rulings.text: No one can cast spells or activate abilities between the time a card is named and the time that Runic Sealer's ability starts to work.
Spells with the chosen name that somehow happen to already be on the stack when Runic Sealer enters the battlefield are not affected by the second ability, only by the third.
Although the named card can't be cast, it can still be put onto the battlefield by a spell or ability (if it's a permanent card).
You can name either half of a split card, but not both. If you do so, that half (and both halves, if the split card has fuse) can't be cast. The other half is unaffected.
If a card with morph is named, that card may still be cast face down. Face-down cards have no names. The same is true for seal, although the card can't be unsealed.
Once Runic Sealer leaves the battlefield, the named card can be cast again.
The third ability stops mana abilities from being activated.

cards.name: Sentry Griffin
cards.originalText:
Flying
{1}, Sacrifice Sentry Griffin: Creatures entering the battlefield don't cause abilities to trigger this turn.

rulings.text: Triggered abilities use the word “when,” “whenever,” or “at.” They're usually written as “[Trigger condition], [effect].”

Replacement effects, such as a permanent entering the battlefield tapped or with counters on it, are unaffected. Abilities that apply “as [this creature] enters the battlefield” are replacement effects.
Sentry Griffin's ability stops a creature's own enters-the-battlefield triggered abilities as well as other triggered abilities that would trigger when a creature enters the battlefield.

The trigger event doesn't have to specify “creatures” entering the battlefield. For example, Contraband Kingpin has an ability that says “Whenever an artifact enters the battlefield under your control, scry 1.” If an artifact creature enters the battlefield under your control, that ability won't trigger. If a noncreature artifact enters the battlefield under your control, the ability will trigger.

Look at the permanent as it exists on the battlefield, taking into account continuous effects, to determine whether any triggered abilities will trigger. For example, if you control March of the Machines, which says, in part, “Each noncreature artifact is an artifact creature,” each artifact will be a creature at the time it enters the battlefield and will not cause triggered abilities to trigger.

cards.name: Travel Together
cards.originalText: If one or more creature tokens would be created under your control, those tokens plus an additional 1/1 white Nomad creature token with vigilance are created instead.

rulings.text: The Nomad token doesn't have any abilities of the other tokens being created. Anything else specified in the effect creating the token(s) (such as tapped, attacking, “Those tokens gain haste,” or “Exile the tokens at end of combat”) also applies to the Nomad token.

If you create a noncreature token that will be a creature as it enters the battlefield, perhaps because of an effect such as that of March of the Machines, Travel Together's effect doesn't apply to that token's creation. (This is because Travel Together's effect modifies how the tokens are created, and March of the Machines's effect doesn't apply until you consider how the tokens are entering the battlefield.)

If an effect changes under whose control a token would be created, that effect applies before Travel Together's effect applies. If an effect changes under whose control a token would enter the battlefield, that effect applies after Travel Together's effect is able to be applied.

cards.name: Quintessence Manta
cards.originalText:
Flash
Flying
When Quintessence Manta enters the battlefield, exile target instant or sorcery spell.
When Quintessence Manta leaves the battlefield, you may cast the exiled card without paying its mana cost.

rulings.text: Spells that can't be countered can be exiled by Quintessence Manta's ability. They won't resolve.

If you cast the exiled card, the spell has no relation to the spell that was originally cast. Any choices made for the original spell or effects affecting the original spell aren't carried over to the new one.

If you cast the exiled card, you do so as part of the resolution of Quintessence Manta's last ability. You can't wait to cast it later in the turn. Timing permissions based on the card's type are ignored, but other restrictions (such as “Cast [this card] only during combat”) are not.

If a player casts a card “without paying its mana cost,” they can't choose to cast it for any alternative costs, such as awaken costs. The player can, however, pay additional costs, such as tithe costs. If the card has any mandatory additional costs, those must be paid to cast the card.
If the card has {X} in its mana cost, you must choose 0 as the value of X when casting it without paying its mana cost.

If Quintessence Manta leaves the battlefield before its enters-the-battlefield triggered ability resolves, its leaves-the-battlefield triggered ability triggers, resolves, and does nothing. Then its first triggered ability resolves and exiles the spell forever.

cards.name: Consign to Failure
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature has "You can't win the game and your opponents can't lose the game."

rulings.text: No game effect can cause the enchanted creature's controller to win the game or cause any of their opponents to lose the game. It doesn't matter whether an opponent has 0 or less life, is forced to draw a card while their library is empty, has ten or more poison counters, is dealt combat damage by Phage the Untouchable, the enchanted creature's controller controls Felidar Sovereign and has 40 or more life, or so on. You keep playing.

Other circumstances can still cause the player to lose the game. They will lose a game if they concede, if they're penalized with a Game Loss or a Match Loss during a tournament due to a rules infraction, or so on.
Effects that say the game is a draw, such as Divine Intervention, are not affected by this effect.

cards.name: Claim What Remains
cards.originalText: Discard a land card: Add {R}, then exile the top card of your library. Until end of turn, you may play that card.

rulings.text: The ability is a mana ability. It doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to.
The card exiled by the ability is exiled face up.
You may play that card that turn even if Claim What Remains is no longer on the battlefield or under your control.

Playing the card exiled with the ability follows the normal rules for playing that card. You must pay its costs, and you must follow all applicable timing rules. For example, if the card is a creature card, you can cast that card by paying its mana cost only during your main phase while the stack is empty.
Unless an effect allows you to play additional lands that turn, you can play a land card exiled with the ability only if you haven't played a land yet that turn.
If you don't play the card, it will remain exiled.

cards.name: The Source
cards.originalText:
Indestructible
{T}, Waste a nonwastes land you control: Add three mana in any combination of colors. (Wastes lose all land types and abilities and gain "{T}: Add {C}.")
As long as you control seven or more wastes, you may play cards you own from outside the game.

rulings.text: In a casual game, a card outside the game comes from your personal collection. In a tournament event, a card outside the game must come from your sideboard. You may look at your sideboard at any time.
A wastes is a permanent named Wastes. A nonwastes land is a land not named Wastes.
Wasting a land changes its name to Wastes, replaces its supertypes and card types with basic land, and removes all other abilities.

{2}, {T}, Sacrifice Source Conduits: Add three mana in any combination of colors. Draw a card.

rulings.text: This is a mana ability, which means it can be activated as part of the process of casting a spell or activating another ability. If that happens you get the mana right away, but you don't get to look at the drawn card until you have finished casting that spell or activating that ability.

cards.name: Stasis Enforcer
cards.originalText:
Each spell a player casts costs {1} more to cast for each other spell that player has cast this turn.
Players may spend mana as though it were mana of any type.

rulings.text: The types of mana are white, blue, black, red, green, and colorless. The second ability doesn't allow players to spend mana as though it were mana from, say, an artifact source or a snow source.

Spending mana as though it were mana of a different type doesn't change what types of mana were spent, only what costs you can pay with that mana. For example, spending {R} as though it were {G} doesn't trigger Ageless Behemoth's ability.

cards.name: Timeless Custodian
cards.originalText:
Vigilance
Timeless Custodian can't have counters put on it.

rulings.text: Timeless Custodian can't have any kind of counters placed on it, not just -1/-1 counters.

Damage from a source with wither or infect has no effect on Timeless Custodian. No -1/-1 counters are placed on it, and no damage is marked on it. The damage is still dealt for purposes of effects that care about damage, such as lifelink.
If Timeless Custodian would enter the battlefield with a counter on it, it simply enters the battlefield without that counter.
If a creature with a counter on it becomes a copy of Timeless Custodian, those counters will remain.
You can't pay a cost that includes putting a counter on Timeless Custodian. For example, you can't torture it.

cards.name: Wastes
cards.originalText: {T}: Add {C}.

rulings.text: The mana ability of Wastes doesn’t appear on the printed cards, but it is in its official Oracle text. (A card’s Oracle text (in English) can be found using the Gatherer card database at Gatherer.Wizards.com.) The printed cards display a large colorless mana symbol in a design that’s similar to other basic land cards.
Because Wastes is a basic land, you can include as many of them as you like in your Constructed decks.

In Limited events (including Sealed Deck and Booster Draft), Wastes must be in your card pool to be included in your deck. You can’t add Wastes to your card pool in the same way that you can add other basic lands.
Wastes is not a land type. If something asks you to name a land type, you can’t choose Wastes.
Similarly, colorless is not a color. If something asks you to choose a color, you can’t choose colorless.
